case_vignette: A 61-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a cough productive of clear mucoid sputum. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 33 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Chest x-ray shows a 2-cm solid nodule in the periphery of the lower left lobe. A bronchial biopsy of the mass shows numerous mucin-filled epithelial cells lining the alveolar basement membrane. The cells have prominent nucleoli, coarse chromatin, and some cells have multiple nuclei.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.

The information doesn't mention any family history of lung problems.
Do you have a history of allergies or asthma?
No, the information doesn't mention any history of allergies or asthma.
Final Diagnosis: Chronic bronchitis secondary to long-term smoking.
